title: ISic003263. Fragmentary funerary inscription of Marcus Vipsanius Phoebus
body:
1 Θ (εοῖς) Κ (αταχθονίοις)
2 Μ (ᾶρκος) Βειψάνιος
3 Φοῖβος ἔζησ (εν) ἔτη
4 κϛ πατὴρ καὶ μή-
5τηρ υἱῷ εὐσεβεῖ

1ΘΚ
2ΜΒΕΙΨΑΝΙΟΣ
3ΦΟΙΒΟΣΕΖΗΣΕΤΗ
4ΚϚΠΑΤΗΡΚΑΙΜΗ
5ΤΗΡΥΙΩΕΥΣΕΒΕΙ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

English translation

Jonathan Prag

To the gods of the underworld. Markos Beipsanios Phoibos (= Marcus Vipsanius Phoebus) lived for 26 years. His father and mother (set this up) for their devoted son.

Italian translation

Serena Agodi

Agli dei sotterranei. Marco Vipsanio Febo visse 26 anni. Il padre e la madre (lo costruirono) per il loro figlio devoto.

commentary

The style of the inscription is quite particular, with variety in letter forms (e.g. the change in the letter E), the frequent use of ligatures (letters joined together), and hedera (ivy leaves) to separate words. Although written in Greek, the text echoes Latin practices, such as the abbreviation Θ Κ (= D M) and also the abbreviation of the Latin praenomen. The spelling of Vipsanius as Beipsanios reflects the common practice from at least the first century AD of transcribing the Latin v as Greek β (although the precise phonetic sound of both letters at this date remains uncertain). On the name Vipsanius, see ISic000383 (inv. no.350).

bibliography

  • 2004.0653 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283
  • 54.0906 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000796
  • 146 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000028
